prompts.name: odoo_common_models
prompts.description: List of commonly used Odoo models
prompts.content:
# Common Odoo Models (v17-19)

## Sales & CRM
- sale.order - Sales Orders
- sale.order.line - Sales Order Lines
- crm.lead - CRM Leads/Opportunities
- crm.team - Sales Teams

## Accounting & Invoicing
- account.move - Invoices & Bills (type: out_invoice, in_invoice, out_refund, in_refund, entry)
- account.move.line - Invoice/Bill Lines
- account.payment - Payments
- account.journal - Journals
- account.account - Chart of Accounts

## Inventory & Warehouse
- stock.picking - Transfers/Deliveries
- stock.move - Stock Moves
- stock.move.line - Stock Move Lines (detailed)
- stock.warehouse - Warehouses
- stock.location - Locations
- stock.quant - Stock Quantities
- stock.lot - Serial/Lot Numbers

## Products
- product.product - Products (variants)
- product.template - Product Templates
- product.category - Product Categories
- uom.uom - Units of Measure
- product.pricelist - Pricelists

## Partners & Contacts
- res.partner - Contacts/Customers/Vendors
- res.company - Companies
- res.users - Users
- res.country - Countries
- res.currency - Currencies

## HR & Employees
- hr.employee - Employees
- hr.department - Departments
- hr.leave - Time Off Requests
- hr.contract - Employee Contracts

## Projects & Tasks
- project.project - Projects
- project.task - Tasks
- project.task.type - Task Stages

## Purchase
- purchase.order - Purchase Orders
- purchase.order.line - Purchase Order Lines

## POS (Point of Sale)
- pos.order - POS Orders
- pos.order.line - POS Order Lines
- pos.session - POS Sessions
- pos.config - POS Configurations

prompts.name: odoo_domain_filters
prompts.description: Guide for Odoo domain filter syntax
prompts.content:
# Odoo Domain Filter Syntax

## Basic Operators
- ['name', '=', 'John'] - Exact match
- ['name', '!=', 'John'] - Not equal
- ['age', '>', 18] - Greater than
- ['age', '>=', 18] - Greater than or equal
- ['age', '<', 65] - Less than
- ['age', '<=', 65] - Less than or equal

## String Operators
- ['name', 'like', 'John'] - Contains (case-sensitive)
- ['name', 'ilike', 'john'] - Contains (case-insensitive)
- ['email', '=like', '%@example.com'] - SQL LIKE pattern
- ['name', '=ilike', 'john%'] - SQL ILIKE pattern

## List Operators
- ['state', 'in', ['draft', 'posted']] - In list
- ['state', 'not in', ['cancel', 'draft']] - Not in list

## Logical Operators (Polish notation)
- ['&', ('a', '=', 1), ('b', '=', 2)] - AND (a=1 AND b=2)
- ['|', ('a', '=', 1), ('a', '=', 2)] - OR (a=1 OR a=2)
- ['!', ('state', '=', 'cancel')] - NOT

## Related Field Filtering
- ['partner_id.country_id.code', '=', 'US'] - Traverse Many2one
- ['order_line.product_id.name', 'ilike', 'laptop'] - Traverse One2many

## Date Filters
- ['create_date', '>=', '2024-01-01']
- ['date_order', '<=', '2024-12-31 23:59:59']

## Complex Examples

# Sales orders > $1000 from US customers
['&', ['state', '=', 'sale'], '&', ['amount_total', '>', 1000], ['partner_id.country_id.code', '=', 'US']]

# Posted invoices from this year
['&', ['state', '=', 'posted'], ['move_type', 'in', ['out_invoice', 'out_refund']], ['invoice_date', '>=', '2024-01-01']]

# Products low on stock
['&', ['type', '=', 'product'], ['qty_available', '<', 10]]

prompts.name: odoo_field_types
prompts.description: Odoo field types and relational fields explained
prompts.content:
# Odoo Field Types

## Basic Fields
- Char - Short text (name, code)
- Text - Long text (description, notes)
- Integer - Whole numbers
- Float - Decimal numbers
- Monetary - Currency amounts (requires currency_id)
- Boolean - True/False
- Date - Date only (YYYY-MM-DD)
- Datetime - Date and time (YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS)
- Selection - Dropdown choices
- Binary - File attachments
- Html - Rich text HTML

## Relational Fields

### Many2one (N:1)
Links to ONE record in another model. Creates FK in database.
- partner_id -> res.partner
- product_id -> product.product
- Access: record.partner_id.name

### One2many (1:N)
Virtual field showing MANY related records. No database column.
- order_ids (on partner) -> sale.order via partner_id
- line_ids (on order) -> sale.order.line via order_id
- Access: for line in record.line_ids: ...

### Many2many (N:N)
Links MANY records to MANY records. Creates junction table.
- tag_ids -> Tags
- user_ids -> Allowed users
- Access: record.tag_ids.mapped('name')

## Computed Fields
Calculated on-the-fly, not stored by default.
- amount_total = sum of line totals
- display_name = computed from name + ref

## Related Fields
Shortcut to access related model's field.
- partner_name = related='partner_id.name'

## Common Conventions
- _id suffix = Many2one (partner_id)
- _ids suffix = One2many/Many2many (line_ids, tag_ids)
- _count suffix = Computed count (sale_order_count)

prompts.name: odoo_workflow_states
prompts.description: Common workflow states for Odoo documents
prompts.content:
# Odoo Document Workflow States

## Sale Order (sale.order)
- draft - Quotation
- sent - Quotation Sent
- sale - Sales Order (confirmed)
- done - Locked
- cancel - Cancelled

## Purchase Order (purchase.order)
- draft - RFQ
- sent - RFQ Sent
- to approve - To Approve
- purchase - Purchase Order
- done - Locked
- cancel - Cancelled

## Invoice/Bill (account.move)
move_type:
- out_invoice - Customer Invoice
- in_invoice - Vendor Bill
- out_refund - Customer Credit Note
- in_refund - Vendor Credit Note
- entry - Journal Entry

state:
- draft - Draft
- posted - Posted
- cancel - Cancelled

payment_state:
- not_paid - Not Paid
- partial - Partially Paid
- paid - Paid
- reversed - Reversed

## Stock Picking (stock.picking)
- draft - Draft
- waiting - Waiting Another Operation
- confirmed - Waiting
- assigned - Ready
- done - Done
- cancel - Cancelled

picking_type_code:
- incoming - Receipts
- outgoing - Delivery Orders
- internal - Internal Transfers

## CRM Lead (crm.lead)
type:
- lead - Lead
- opportunity - Opportunity

## Project Task (project.task)
Uses stage_id (Many2one to project.task.type)
Common stages: New, In Progress, Done, Cancelled

## POS Order (pos.order)
- draft - New
- paid - Paid
- done - Posted
- invoiced - Invoiced
- cancel - Cancelled

prompts.name: odoo_read_group
prompts.description: How to use read_group for aggregation and reporting
prompts.content:
# Odoo read_group() - Aggregation Guide

read_group performs GROUP BY queries with aggregation at database level.

## Syntax
model.read_group(
    domain,      # Filter: [] for all
    fields,      # ['field:agg'] or ['field']
    groupby,     # ['field'] or ['field:timespan']
    offset=0,
    limit=None,
    orderby=False,
    lazy=True
)

## Aggregation Functions
- sum - Total
- count - Count records
- avg - Average
- min - Minimum
- max - Maximum

## Examples

### Count orders by state
{
  "model": "sale.order",
  "method": "read_group",
  "args": [[], ["id:count"], ["state"]]
}

### Sum sales by customer
{
  "model": "sale.order",
  "method": "read_group",
  "args": [
    [["state", "=", "sale"]],
    ["amount_total:sum"],
    ["partner_id"]
  ]
}

### Monthly revenue
{
  "model": "account.move",
  "method": "read_group",
  "args": [
    [["state", "=", "posted"], ["move_type", "=", "out_invoice"]],
    ["amount_total:sum"],
    ["invoice_date:month"]
  ]
}

### Product sales by category
{
  "model": "sale.order.line",
  "method": "read_group",
  "args": [
    [["state", "=", "sale"]],
    ["price_subtotal:sum", "product_uom_qty:sum"],
    ["product_id.categ_id"]
  ]
}

## Time Grouping Options
- date_field:day
- date_field:week
- date_field:month
- date_field:quarter
- date_field:year

## Notes
- Returns list of dicts, not recordsets
- Many2one fields return (id, name) tuples
- Only stored fields can be grouped
- __count is always included

prompts.name: odoo_context
prompts.description: Odoo context parameters and their usage

prompts.name: odoo_api_tips
prompts.description: Best practices for Odoo API usage
prompts.content:
# Odoo API Best Practices

## Performance Tips

### 1. Limit fields in search_read
Don't fetch all fields, specify only what you need:
- Good: fields=["name", "state", "amount_total"]
- Bad: fields=[] (fetches everything)

### 2. Use pagination
For large datasets, use offset and limit:
- limit=100, offset=0 (first page)
- limit=100, offset=100 (second page)

### 3. Use read_group for aggregation
Instead of fetching all records and summing in code:
- Bad: search_read all orders, sum in loop
- Good: read_group with sum aggregation

### 4. Avoid search in loops
Batch your operations:
- Bad: for id in ids: search([('id','=',id)])
- Good: search([('id','in',ids)])

## Field Selection Tips

### Many2one fields
Returns [id, name] tuple:
- partner_id -> [42, "John Doe"]
Access: result['partner_id'][0] for ID, [1] for name

### Selection fields
Returns key, not label:
- state -> 'sale' (not 'Sales Order')
Use fields_get to get labels if needed

### Date/Datetime
Returns string in ISO format:
- date -> '2024-01-15'
- datetime -> '2024-01-15 10:30:00'

## Common Patterns

### Check if record exists
{
  "model": "res.partner",
  "domain": [["email", "=", "test@example.com"]],
  "limit": 1,
  "fields": ["id"]
}

### Get record with related data
{
  "model": "sale.order",
  "domain": [["id", "=", 123]],
  "fields": [
    "name", "state", "amount_total",
    "partner_id",
    "order_line",  // Returns IDs only
    "partner_id.email"  // Related field
  ]
}

### Fetch One2many details
1. Get order: search_read sale.order
2. Get lines: search_read sale.order.line where order_id = X

## Error Handling
- Check 'error' key in response
- Common errors: Access denied, Record not found, Validation error
